content.description: Start as you would for the V0 arete, and then move up and right topping out on a sloper rail.
content.protection: A pad and maybe a spotter.
content.location: Begin the same as for the V0 start.

content.description:
Start just to the right of

The Main Squeeze

and on the far left side of the north face of the boulder below what looks like a slabby section. Follow the edges and slab to a huge jug on the lip. It's fun.
content.location:
It is on the far left of the north face of the Corkscrew Boulder just to the right of

The Main Squeeze

.

content.description: Start on the obvious crimpy edges low and left. Move up and right over a multi-dimensional bulge heading to an obvious horizontal rail with good holds.  Pull around the corner and y'er done. You could finish up by continuing straight up the ~30 foot arete, but I feel like that would be a different climb.
content.location: This traverses the West face of the Corkscrew Boulder (facing the road).

content.description:
Start at the overhanging corner, and pull up the arete. Follow good face and arete holds to the top. This is fun and easy.

This route has been here forever, I am just adding it for clarification.
content.location:
It is on the opposite corner of the boulder as

Corkscrew

.

content.description:
Rock Out starts same as

The Main Squeeze

and makes a few moves up the arete. Then rock out right over the arete grabbing an obvious, undercling, sidepull edge. Stand up, and make the easy topout on jugs.
content.protection: It has a flat landing. Use two to three pads.
content.location:
Use the same start as

The Main Squeeze

, sit start with your left hand on the underside of the boulder on a good crimp and your right hand on a good sloper on the arete.

content.description:
The route starts low under the steep arete to the right of

Corkscrew

.  Using arete holds and crimps on the roof, squeeze and hook your way through the steep arete and up the short, vertical arete to the finishing break of

Corkscrew

.  (One book calls it V6, but I think that is the stand start one move wonder on the vertical section of the arete.)
content.protection: 2 pads (one if you don't mind a little sand).
content.location:
This is just right of

Corkscrew

on the steep arete.

content.description:
Stand start with both hands on the undercling just above the

Corkscrew

starting block. This is not as cool as the (sit-start) twisty

Corkscrew

beta, but it is still something to be proud of. It is harder than any V4 I've done, but it may not be a V5.
Be prepared to scratch your head at this one. Start on the obvious flat rail, and make you way up the corner.
content.location: This is the first problem you come to when you arrive at the Corkscrew Boulder.

content.description: The literature calls it V6, but most will find it harder.  Start with your right hand in a well hidden undercling that is under the 12" high roof (feel around to find it) and your left in the smooth round sidepull.  Move up through the sloper at 6 feet and slap, crimp and pray through the topout (crux).  The big grey undercling that is out to the left at 5feet off the ground is off.
content.protection: One pad and maybe some webbing to tie back the pine branches.
content.location:
The route is just left of

Corkscrew

and is one of the first things you come to from the road.

climbs.name: The Battle of the Bulge - Left Exit

content.description:
Do the same start as

The Battle of the Bulge

, but use that awesome undercling that the main

Battle of the Bulge

problem explicitly mentions to avoid. You'll end up mantling on the left side of the bulge. It's fun. Do it.
content.location:
This is just left of the

Corkscrew

.
